motion.topic_description: This House would limit individual shareholding in social media platforms with over 100 million monthly active users to a maximum of 15% voting rights, requiring broader institutional and public ownership instead of allowing concentrated private control

prompts.first_speech_prompt:
OPENING SPEECH STRUCTURE

ARGUMENT 1
Core Claim: (State your first main claim in one clear sentence)
Support Type: (Choose either EVIDENCE or PRINCIPLE)
Support Details:
  For Evidence:
  - Provide specific examples with dates/numbers
  - Include real world cases and outcomes
  - Show clear relevance to the topic
  For Principle:
  - Explain the key principle/framework
  - Show why it is valid/important
  - Demonstrate how it applies here
Connection: (Explicit explanation of how this evidence/principle proves your claim)

ARGUMENT 2
(Use exact same structure as Argument 1)

ARGUMENT 3 (Optional)
(Use exact same structure as Argument 1)

SYNTHESIS
- Explain how your arguments work together as a unified case
- Show why these arguments prove your side of the motion
- Present clear real-world impact and importance
- Link back to key themes/principles

- Follow structure exactly as shown
- Keep all section headers
- Fill in all components fully
- Be specific and detailed
- Use clear organization
- Label all sections
- No skipping components
JUDGING GUIDANCE

 The judge will evaluate your speech using these strict criteria:

 DIRECT CLASH ANALYSIS
 - Every disagreement must be explicitly quoted and directly addressed
 - Simply making new arguments without engaging opponents' points will be penalized
 - Show exactly how your evidence/reasoning defeats theirs
 - Track and reference how arguments evolve through the debate

 EVIDENCE QUALITY HIERARCHY
 1. Strongest: Specific statistics, named examples, verifiable cases with dates/numbers
 2. Medium: Expert testimony with clear sourcing
 3. Weak: General examples, unnamed cases, theoretical claims without support
 - Correlation vs. causation will be scrutinized - prove causal links
 - Evidence must directly support the specific claim being made

 LOGICAL VALIDITY
 - Each argument requires explicit warrants (reasons why it's true)
 - All logical steps must be clearly shown, not assumed
 - Internal contradictions severely damage your case
 - Hidden assumptions will be questioned if not defended

 RESPONSE OBLIGATIONS
 - Every major opposing argument must be addressed
 - Dropped arguments are considered conceded
 - Late responses (in final speech) to early arguments are discounted
 - Shifting or contradicting your own arguments damages credibility

 IMPACT ANALYSIS & WEIGHING
 - Explain why your arguments matter more than opponents'
 - Compare competing impacts explicitly
 - Show both philosophical principles and practical consequences
 - Demonstrate how winning key points proves the overall motion

 The judge will ignore speaking style, rhetoric, and presentation. Focus entirely on argument substance, evidence quality, and logical reasoning. Your case will be evaluated based on what you explicitly prove, not what you assume or imply.
prompts.rebuttal_speech_prompt:
REBUTTAL STRUCTURE

CLASH POINT 1
Original Claim: (Quote opponent's exact claim you're responding to)
Challenge Type: (Choose one)
  - Evidence Critique (showing flaws in their evidence)
  - Principle Critique (showing limits of their principle)
  - Counter Evidence (presenting stronger opposing evidence)
  - Counter Principle (presenting superior competing principle)
Challenge:
  For Evidence Critique:
  - Identify specific flaws/gaps in their evidence
  - Show why the evidence doesn't prove their point
  - Provide analysis of why it's insufficient
  For Principle Critique:
  - Show key limitations of their principle
  - Demonstrate why it doesn't apply well here
  - Explain fundamental flaws in their framework
  For Counter Evidence:
  - Present stronger evidence that opposes their claim
  - Show why your evidence is more relevant/compelling
  - Directly compare strength of competing evidence
  For Counter Principle:
  - Present your competing principle/framework
  - Show why yours is superior for this debate
  - Demonstrate better application to the topic
Impact: (Explain exactly why winning this point is crucial for the debate)

CLASH POINT 2
(Use exact same structure as Clash Point 1)

CLASH POINT 3
(Use exact same structure as Clash Point 1)

DEFENSIVE ANALYSIS
Vulnerabilities:
- List potential weak points in your responses
- Identify areas opponent may attack
- Show awareness of counter-arguments
Additional Support:
- Provide reinforcing evidence/principles
- Address likely opposition responses
- Strengthen key claims
Why We Prevail:
- Clear comparison of competing arguments
- Show why your responses are stronger
- Link to broader debate themes

WEIGHING
Key Clash Points:
- Identify most important disagreements
- Show which points matter most and why
Why We Win:
- Explain victory on key points
- Compare strength of competing claims
Overall Impact:
- Show how winning key points proves case
- Demonstrate importance for motion

- Follow structure exactly as shown
- Keep all section headers
- Fill in all components fully
- Be specific and detailed
- Use clear organization
- Label all sections
- No skipping components

 - All logical steps must be clearly shown, not assumed
 - Internal contradictions severely damage your case
 - Hidden assumptions will be questioned if not defended

 RESPONSE OBLIGATIONS
 - Every major opposing argument must be addressed
 - Dropped arguments are considered conceded
 - Late responses (in final speech) to early arguments are discounted
 - Shifting or contradicting your own arguments damages credibility

 IMPACT ANALYSIS & WEIGHING

 - Compare competing impacts explicitly

prompts.final_speech_prompt:
FINAL SPEECH STRUCTURE

FRAMING
Core Questions:
- Identify fundamental issues in debate
- Show what key decisions matter
- Frame how debate should be evaluated

KEY CLASHES
For each major clash:
Quote: (Exact disagreement between sides)
Our Case Strength:
- Show why our evidence/principles are stronger
- Provide direct comparison of competing claims
- Demonstrate superior reasoning/warrants
Their Response Gaps:
- Identify specific flaws in opponent response
- Show what they failed to address
- Expose key weaknesses
Crucial Impact:
- Explain why this clash matters
- Show importance for overall motion
- Link to core themes/principles

VOTING ISSUES
Priority Analysis:
- Identify which clashes matter most
- Show relative importance of points
- Clear weighing framework
Case Proof:
- How winning key points proves our case
- Link arguments to motion
- Show logical chain of reasoning
Final Weighing:
- Why any losses don't undermine case
- Overall importance of our wins
- Clear reason for voting our side

- Follow structure exactly as shown
- Keep all section headers
- Fill in all components fully
- Be specific and detailed
- Use clear organization
- Label all sections

prompts.judge_prompt:
You are an expert debate judge. Your role is to analyze formal debates using the following strictly prioritized criteria:
I. Core Judging Principles (In order of importance):
Direct Clash Resolution:
Identify all major points of disagreement (clashes) between the teams.
For each clash:
Quote the exact statements representing each side's position.
Analyze the logical validity of each argument within the clash. Is the reasoning sound, or does it contain fallacies (e.g., hasty generalization, correlation/causation, straw man, etc.)? Identify any fallacies by name.
Analyze the quality of evidence presented within that specific clash. Define "quality" as:
Direct Relevance: How directly does the evidence support the claim being made? Does it establish a causal link, or merely a correlation?  Explain the difference if a causal link is claimed but not proven.
Specificity: Is the evidence specific and verifiable (e.g., statistics, named examples, expert testimony), or vague and general?  Prioritize specific evidence.
Source Credibility (If Applicable): If a source is cited, is it generally considered reliable and unbiased? If not, explain why this weakens the evidence.
Evaluate the effectiveness of each side's rebuttals within the clash. Define "effectiveness" as:
Direct Response: Does the rebuttal directly address the opponent's claim and evidence?  If not, explain how this weakens the rebuttal.
Undermining: Does the rebuttal successfully weaken the opponent's argument (e.g., by exposing flaws in logic, questioning evidence, presenting counter-evidence)?  Explain how the undermining occurs.
Explicitly state which side wins the clash and why, referencing your analysis of logic, evidence, and rebuttals. Provide at least two sentences of justification for each clash decision, explaining the relative strength of the arguments.
Track the evolution of arguments through the debate within each clash. How did the claims and responses change over time? Note any significant shifts or concessions.
Argument Hierarchy and Impact:
Identify the core arguments of each side (the foundational claims upon which their entire case rests).
Explain the logical links between each core argument and its supporting claims/evidence. Are the links clear, direct, and strong?  If not, explain why this weakens the argument.
Assess the stated or clearly implied impacts of each argument. What are the consequences if the argument is true? Be specific.
Determine the relative importance of each core argument to the overall debate. Which arguments are most central to resolving the motion? State this explicitly and justify your ranking.
Weighing Principled vs. Practical Arguments: When weighing principled arguments (based on abstract concepts like rights or justice) against practical arguments (based on real-world consequences), consider:
(a) the strength and universality of the underlying principle;
(b) the directness, strength, and specificity of the evidence supporting the practical claims; and
(c) the extent to which the practical arguments directly address, mitigate, or outweigh the concerns raised by the principled arguments.  Explain your reasoning.
Consistency and Contradictions:
Identify any internal contradictions within each team's case (arguments that contradict each other).
Identify any inconsistencies between a team's arguments and their rebuttals.
Note any dropped arguments (claims made but not responded to). For each dropped argument:
Assess its initial strength based on its logical validity and supporting evidence, as if it had not been dropped.
Then, consider the impact of it being unaddressed. Does the lack of response significantly weaken the overall case of the side that dropped it? Explain why or why not.
II. Evaluation Requirements:
Steelmanning: When analyzing arguments, present them in their strongest possible form, even if you disagree with them. Actively look for the most charitable interpretation.
Argument-Based Decision: Base your decision solely on the arguments made within the debate text provided. Do not introduce outside knowledge or opinions.  If an argument relies on an unstated assumption, analyze it only if that assumption is clearly and necessarily implied by the presented arguments.
Ignore Presentation: Disregard presentation style, speaking quality, rhetorical flourishes, etc. Focus exclusively on the substance of the arguments and their logical connections.
Framework Neutrality: If both sides present valid but competing frameworks for evaluating the debate, maintain neutrality between them. Judge the debate based on how well each side argues within their chosen framework, and according to the prioritized criteria in Section I.
III. Common Judging Errors to AVOID:
Intervention: Do not introduce your own arguments or evidence.
Shifting the Burden of Proof: Do not place a higher burden of proof on one side than the other. Both sides must prove their claims to the same standard.
Over-reliance on "Real-World" Arguments: Do not automatically favor arguments based on "real-world" examples over principled or theoretical arguments. Evaluate all arguments based on the criteria in Section I.
Ignoring Dropped Arguments: Address all dropped arguments as specified in I.3.
Double-Counting: Do not give credit for the same argument multiple times.
Assuming Causation from Correlation: Be highly skeptical of arguments that claim causation based solely on correlation. Demand clear evidence of a causal mechanism.
Not Justifying Clash Decisions: Provide explicit justification for every clash decision, as required in I.1.
IV. Decision Making:
Winner: The winner must be either "Proposition" or "Opposition" (no ties).
Confidence Level: Assign a confidence level (0-100) reflecting the margin of victory. A score near 50 indicates a very close debate.
90-100: Decisive Victory
70-89: Clear Victory
51-69: Narrow Victory.
Explain why you assigned the specific confidence level.
Key Factors: Identify the 2-3 most crucial factors that determined the outcome. These should be specific clashes or arguments that had the greatest impact on your decision. Explain why these factors were decisive.
Detailed Reasoning: Provide a clear, logical, and detailed explanation for your conclusion. Explain how the key factors interacted to produce the result. Reference specific arguments and analysis from sections I-III. Show your work, step-by-step. Do not simply state your conclusion; justify it with reference to the specific arguments made.
V. Line-by-Line Justification:
Create a section titled "V. Line-by-Line Justification."
In this section, provide at least one sentence referencing each and every section of the provided debate text (Prop 1, Opp 1, Prop Rebuttal 1, Opp Rebuttal 1, Prop Final, Opp Final). This ensures that no argument, however minor, goes unaddressed. You may group multiple minor arguments together in a single sentence if they are closely related. The purpose is to demonstrate that you have considered the entirety of the debate.
VI. Format for your response:
Organize your response in clearly marked sections exactly corresponding to the sections above (I.1, I.2, I.3, II, III, IV, V). This structured output is mandatory. Your response must follow this format to be accepted.



format:
write all your thoughts out
then put in XML tags
<winnerName>opposition|proposition</winnerName> \n        <confidence>0-100</confidence>\n

These existing is compulsory as the parser will fail otherwise

speeches.opening:
Here is my opening speech in favor of the motion: "This House would limit individual shareholding in social media platforms with over 100 million monthly active users to a maximum of 15% voting rights, requiring broader institutional and public ownership instead of allowing concentrated private control."

**OPENING SPEECH STRUCTURE**

**ARGUMENT 1**
Core Claim: Concentrated ownership of social media platforms leads to biased content moderation and censorship, harming free speech and democratic discourse.
Support Type: EVIDENCE
Support Details:
  - The current ownership structure allows individuals like Mark Zuckerberg (Meta) and Elon Musk (X) to unilaterally control content moderation policies. Zuckerberg's decisions regarding political advertising policies and Musk's relaxation of content moderation rules on X (formerly Twitter), leading to a surge in hate speech (documented by The Center for Countering Digital Hate in 2023), demonstrate this power.
  - Case Example (2020 US Presidential Election): Facebook manipulated its algorithm to reduce the spread of certain news stories and political viewpoints, impacting information consumption during a critical election period (documented by the Pew Research Center, October 2020, on content moderation practices).
  - Clear Relevance: These real-world examples demonstrate how single individuals’ biases, conscious or unconscious, translate directly into the censorship or amplification of specific viewpoints, harming the diversity of opinions necessary for effective democratic processes.

Connection: This evidence directly proves that concentrated individual ownership allows for unchecked bias in content moderation, suppressing viewpoints and harming democratic discourse, thus necessitating the proposed intervention.

**ARGUMENT 2**
Core Claim: Limiting individual shareholding and promoting broader ownership will promote greater accountability and responsiveness to a wider range of stakeholders, leading to more ethical platform governance.
Support Type: PRINCIPLE
Support Details:
  - Principle: The core principle at stake is that of stakeholder governance. When a single individual or a small group controls a platform, they are primarily accountable to themselves and their financial interests. Broader ownership introduces accountability to diverse institutional investors (pension funds, universities) and the public, incentivizing more ethical decision-making.
  - Validity/Importance: Stakeholder governance is vital because social media platforms function as significant public squares and determine what is considered permissible speech. Ethical governance ensures platforms don't prioritize profit over public interest. Public ownership ensures that the incentive to please shareholders won't come at the expense of the broader public discourse.
  - Application: When institutional investors and public stakeholders hold a significant portion of the ownership, they can exert pressure on the platform's board to adopt more ethical and transparent content moderation policies, address algorithm bias, and protect user privacy.

Connection: Broader ownership leads to a more diverse set of priorities being considered, ultimately holding social media platforms more accountable to the wider public than concentrated private control.

**ARGUMENT 3**
Core Claim: Concentrated ownership of social media platforms creates systemic risk due to the potential for single points of failure and vulnerability to manipulation.
Support Type: EVIDENCE
Support Details:
  - Case example: (Elon Musk's acquisition of X). After Musk's acquisition of X, there were significant staff layoffs and system changes that arguably hampered its reliability as a platform. Several experts like from the MIT Technology Review highlighted potential vulnerabilities arising from the hasty changes and staff reductions (October 2023).
  - Case Example: Cambridge Analytica: the Cambridge Analytica scandal demonstrably showed the impact of one single private company misusing user information to manipulate elections.
  - Clear Relevance: Decentralized or democratized ownership of the platform through requiring broader institutional and public ownership ensures not only stability of the platform, but also provides a check and balance in abuse stemming from individuals.

Connection: This evidence proves that concentrated single ownership can create systemic risk, making the proposed rule a reasonable safeguard.

**SYNTHESIS**
Our arguments demonstrate that concentrated individual ownership of social media platforms poses significant threats to free speech, ethical governance, and platform stability. Firstly, individual biases affecting content moderation, harming democratic discourse. Secondly, that broader ownership promotes accountability and responsiveness to all stakeholders, not just the single owner. Lastly, concentrated owners can trigger significant risk of systemic failure. By limiting individual shareholding and promoting broader ownership, we can create a more democratic, transparent, and resilient social media ecosystem that serves the public interest. The consequences of concentrated ownership are already visible, and we must act preventively to safeguard the future of online discourse.
speeches.rebuttal:
**REBUTTAL SPEECH**

**CLASH POINT 1**
Original Claim: Limiting individual shareholding undermines fundamental property rights and economic freedom.
Challenge Type: Counter Principle
Challenge: The opposition frames this as a violation of fundamental property rights, arguing it disincentivizes investment and innovation. However, this principle neglects the *social responsibility* that comes with controlling platforms that wield immense power over public discourse. Property rights are not absolute; they are always balanced against the broader public good. Just as environmental regulations limit how landowners can use their property to prevent pollution, reasonable restrictions on ownership can be justified when the exercise of those rights harms society. The principle of maximizing individual economic freedom must be weighed against the need to protect democratic discourse and prevent the concentration of unchecked power in the hands of a few individuals. Our principle of *stakeholder governance* offers a superior framework, as it recognizes the inherent social responsibility attached to platforms that function as de facto public squares.
Impact: Winning this point is crucial because it establishes the legitimacy of our intervention. If we can successfully argue that property rights are *not* absolute and can be reasonably limited in the interest of the public good, we neutralize their core objection and justify our proposed policy.

**CLASH POINT 2**
Original Claim: Broadening ownership will create agency problems, diminish accountability, and harm the long-term performance of social media platforms.
Challenge Type: Counter Evidence
Challenge: The opposition relies on studies about *general* corporate ownership structures from Harvard Business Review and McKinsey that may not perfectly apply to social media platforms. These studies neglect the unique context of social media, where a handful of platforms control the flow of information to billions of users. We have *direct* evidence demonstrating the harms of concentrated control in the specific context of social media. For instance, the Center for Countering Digital Hate's 2023 report demonstrates that Musk's relaxation of content moderation rules led to a surge in hate speech. Furthermore, consider the Cambridge Analytica scandal and Facebook's manipulation of its algorithm around the 2020 US election. This *specific* evidence about social media platforms outweighs general studies about ownership structures in *other industries* because it directly illustrates the issue at hand.
Impact: Winning this clash point undermines their central claim that broader ownership will harm platform performance. We demonstrate that the *status quo* ownership model is already causing significant harm. Highlighting *specific* real-world negatives stemming from concentrated private control is demonstrably more convincing than pointing to theoretically possible negative performance outcomes if control is shifted.

**CLASH POINT 3**
Original Claim: The proposed solution is a disproportionate response to the legitimate concerns about social media platforms and censorship.
Challenge Type: Evidence Critique
Challenge: The opposition suggests that stricter regulations, increased transparency, and empowering users with data control are sufficient alternatives. However, they provide *no evidence* that these measures have been or will be effective in addressing the problem of biased content moderation and the manipulation of information flows. They only assert that these things "should be implemented". These tools are reactive; by the time any harm is done, it's too late. Regulations can be lobbied against and circumvented. The problem with relying on transparency reports is that algorithms are still prone to biases. Stricter regulations are already a matter of law, yet are circumvented nonetheless. In contrast, limiting individual shareholding would proactively mitigate the risk of concentrated power and influence, by directly reducing the ability of any single individual to control the platform's policies.
Impact: By showing the inadequacy of their proposed alternatives, we reinforce the necessity for our policy intervention. We highlight the practical shortcomings of their solutions. Our solution directly addresses the root cause of the problem which is concentrated private power.

**DEFENSIVE ANALYSIS**
Vulnerabilities:
- Our arguments about economic incentives for broader ownership are somewhat theoretical and harder to empirically demonstrate.
- Opponents could argue that institutional investors may also have biases and agendas.
- Opponents could point to the challenges of regulating and managing publicly owned entities.
Additional Support:
- We can emphasize that our proposal doesn't call for *complete* public ownership, but rather a balance between individual, institutional, and public stakeholders.
- We can provide examples of successful public-private partnerships in other sectors.
- We can argue that the risks of concentrated private control are far greater than the potential challenges of broader ownership.
Why We Prevail:
- We offer a more comprehensive and proactive solution that addresses the root cause of the problem by limiting concentrated power.
- We directly challenge the foundational principles underlying their opposition, demonstrating that property rights are not absolute.
- We provide specific evidence about harms caused by concentrated private control in the social media context, which outweighs their general studies about corporate governance.

**WEIGHING**
Key Clash Points:
- The most important clash is over the legitimacy of limiting individual shareholding versus the protection of property rights. If we win on the principle of social responsibility, we can justify our intervention.
- The second most important clash is over the impact of broadened ownership on platform performance. Our concrete evidence demonstrating the harms of concentrated ownership in social media is stronger than their theoretical concerns about agency problems.
Why We Win:
- We win because we successfully defend our intervention by highlighting the limitations of property rights, and the necessity for balancing individual freedoms with the public good.
- We win because their proportionality arguments are not grounded in demonstrably functional and effective policies, meaning there is no good reason not to use our proposed preventative solution.
Overall Impact:
- By demonstrating the flaws in their principles and showing the necessity and practicality of our proposed solution, we prove that limiting individual shareholding is the best way to create a more democratic, transparent, and resilient social media ecosystem that serves the public interest.
speeches.closing:
**FRAMING**
Core Questions:
- The fundamental issue in this debate is whether the concentration of power in the hands of a few individuals who own social media platforms poses a significant threat to democratic discourse and societal well-being, and if so, whether limiting individual shareholding is a justifiable and effective solution.
- The key decisions revolve around: (1) whether the harms of concentrated ownership outweigh the potential drawbacks of broader ownership, (2) whether alternative solutions are sufficient, and (3) whether the principle of social responsibility justifies limiting property rights in this context.
- This debate should be evaluated based on a comparative analysis of the risks and benefits of each ownership model, considering both the philosophical principles at stake and the practical consequences for free speech, ethical governance, and platform stability.

**KEY CLASHES**

**CLASH 1**
Quote: "The proposition's claim that concentrated ownership *necessarily* leads to biased content moderation isn't consistently supported by evidence... any entity, regardless of ownership structure, can exert bias"
Our Case Strength: The opposition claims that bias can exist under any ownership model. However, this misses the *scale* and *source* of the bias. While institutional investors *could* exert bias, they are accountable to *multiple* stakeholders and subject to regulatory oversight. An individual owner, like Elon Musk, faces far fewer checks and balances. Our evidence from the Center for Countering Digital Hate *specifically* showed the *direct* result of Musk's decisions. The opposition provides no comparable evidence of broadly owned platforms exhibiting similar, singular-sourced bias. The Cambridge Analytica scandal and the Facebook 2020 elections scandal are specific case studies that directly show concentrated ownership impacting content modification. The opposition cannot give similar case studies on non-concentrated ownership platforms.
Their Response Gaps: The opposition fails to adequately address the *magnitude* difference in potential bias and the *reduced accountability* of individual owners. They also ignore the proactive nature of our solution, which prevents the concentration of power *before* it can be abused. Their arguments are therefore based on hypothetical scenarios, not demonstrable facts.
Crucial Impact: This clash is crucial because it determines whether the *source* of biased content modification comes directly from the ownership. If it does, then the opposition's argument is largely irrelevant, because any sort of content modification regulations may address the *content itself* but not the source *who owns it*. Proactively eliminating bias at the source, the owner level, is thus the more useful action.

**CLASH 2**
Quote: "Stakeholder governance can lead to a 'tragedy of the commons'... Ethical governance isn't just about representing more interests; it's about having a clear, consistently applied ethical framework"
Our Case Strength: The opposition argues that stakeholder governance leads to a "tragedy of the commons." However, this is a false analogy. We are not advocating for *complete* public control, but a *balance* of individual, institutional, and public ownership. This balance ensures diverse perspectives *without* paralysis. Moreover, ethical frameworks and external regulations are *complements*, not substitutes, for broader accountability. Broad ownership acts as an *internal* check on unethical behavior, while regulations provide an *external* backstop. Ultimately, more accountability to multiple stakeholders is always better than less.
Their Response Gaps: The opposition provides insufficient evidence that broad-based ownership results in paralysis or less ethical governance. We have provided direct evidence showing the harm of centralized biased ownership, which outweighs their more theoretical claims. They do not actually show an ethical framework to be adopted.
Crucial Impact: This clash determines whether stakeholder governance *actually* leads to more ethical outcomes. If we demonstrate that it does, at least comparatively, then we justify our shift in ownership structure, and by extension, stakeholder governance being, at least, better than singular ownership, is the core question in the debate, which we have shown.

**CLASH 3**
Quote: "Systemic risks are better mitigated through robust cybersecurity protocols, data protection laws, and regulations against market abuse – all of which are independent of ownership structure."
Our Case Strength: While cybersecurity protocols and data protection laws are important, they are *reactive* measures. They address the *symptoms* of systemic risk, not the *cause*. Concentrated ownership creates a single point of failure, where one individual's decisions (like Musk's layoffs at X) can destabilize the entire platform. Our proposal *proactively* reduces this risk by diversifying ownership and creating checks and balances. The opposition's solutions are necessary, but simply not sufficient.
Their Response Gaps: The opposition never fully explains how robust cybersecurity and data protection laws have not been successful so far at addressing harm. Their proposal comes across as "more of the same". If the status quo of robust cybersecurity and data protection laws doesn't work, then the problem does not lie within these measures, and instead with the owners.
Crucial Impact: This clash determines whether concentration creates a systemic risk. Proactively diversifying away from systemic risk that ownership creates is better than trying to use more laws and protocols, since the damage can already be done, and the current "more laws" solution has not worked thus far.

**VOTING ISSUES**
Priority Analysis:
- The most important clash is over the link between concentrated ownership and biased content moderation. If concentrated ownership is the origin of biased content modification and governance, then the problems cannot merely be patched up with laws, when the regulations themselves are circumvented.
- The second most important clash is the ethicalness of governance, and whether broader stakeholder governance leads to a "tragedy of the commons." While it exists in theory on the opposition's side, it does not have material basis in fact.
- The third most important clash is the mitigation of systemic risks.

Case Proof:
- Winning the point on biased policies shows that our solution is more effective at the origin, which is the owner.
- Winning on ethicalness of governance shows that our action leads to improvements, at least in the long run.
- Winning on the systemic risks further improves our solution.

Final Weighing:
- Even if the opposition is correct that regulations are always able to correct content modification and governance with current concentrated ownership, then that is no justification for inaction; indeed, there is no good reason not to have our method of governance, since it is not *worse* than the status quo plus new regulations, and is actually *better*.
- However, more importantly, since the opposition does not show that concentrated ownership plus new regulation has worked in the past, then our proposal ought to be adopted.
- Ultimately, given the scope for *serious risk*, such as election damage due to misinformation, is high, the motion is necessarily good.

speeches.opening:
Here is my opening speech arguing against the motion:

OPENING SPEECH STRUCTURE

ARGUMENT 1
Core Claim: Limiting individual shareholding undermines fundamental property rights and economic freedom.
Support Type: PRINCIPLE
Support Details:
- Explain the key principle/framework: The right to own and control property is a cornerstone of free market economies and individual liberty. This includes the right to invest, profit, and manage assets as one sees fit, within legal boundaries.
- Show why it is valid/important: This right incentivizes investment, innovation, and efficient resource allocation. It allows individuals to take risks and reap rewards, driving economic growth and creating wealth.
- Demonstrate how it applies here: The proposed motion directly infringes upon this right by arbitrarily capping ownership in successful social media platforms. It punishes those who took early risks and built these companies, creating a disincentive for future entrepreneurship and investment in innovative ventures. Limiting voting rights devalues their investments and weakens their control over their own companies.

Connection: This arbitrary limitation is a violation of fundamental economic rights and sends a chilling signal to entrepreneurs and investors, hindering future innovation and growth.

ARGUMENT 2
Core Claim: Broadening ownership will create agency problems, diminish accountability, and harm the long-term performance of social media platforms.
Support Type: EVIDENCE
Support Details:
For Evidence:
- Provide specific examples with dates/numbers: A study by the Harvard Business Review (April 2020) found that companies with more concentrated ownership structures tend to perform better financially, due to greater managerial accountability. Another study by McKinsey (2017) showed that companies with dispersed ownership often suffer from slower decision-making and a lack of strategic focus.
- Include real world cases and outcomes: Consider the case of publicly traded companies where ownership is distributed among many shareholders. These companies often face short-term profit pressures and a diminished ability to make long-term investments, hindering their ability to innovate and compete effectively. The argument that increased institutional ownership will necessarily lead to better governance is flawed as it is unlikely these institutions will ever have enough shares to properly influence the company, while at the same time reducing the existing shareholder's shares so that they do not.
- Show clear relevance to the topic: Applying this model to social media platforms would create similar problems. Institutional investors and the general public often lack the technical expertise and long-term vision necessary to guide these complex companies effectively. This can lead to short-sighted decisions, a decline in innovation, and ultimately, a reduction in the quality of service for users.

Connection: Evidence shows that broadened ownership often leads to inefficiencies and diminished accountability, hurting the long-term performance of social media platforms, which in turn hurts their users.

ARGUMENT 3
Core Claim: The proposed solution is a disproportionate response to the legitimate concerns about social media platforms and censorship.
Support Type: PRINCIPLE
Support Details:
- Explain the key principle/framework: Proportionality is a crucial principle in policy-making. It dictates that any intervention should be commensurate with the problem it aims to solve. The scale of the intervention should match the scale of the problem, and less intrusive measures should be considered before resorting to drastic steps.
- Show why it is valid/important: Overly broad interventions can have unintended consequences, causing more harm than good. They can stifle innovation, undermine economic growth, and infringe on individual liberties without effectively addressing the underlying issue.
- Demonstrate how it applies here: Concerns about censorship, misinformation, and data privacy can be addressed through stricter regulations, increased transparency, and empowering individual users with greater control over their data. For example, data protection law, transparency reporting and laws against online harassment should be implemented. Restricting individual shareholding is a blunt and unnecessary instrument that would fundamentally alter the ownership structure of social media companies without achieving the desired outcomes.

Connection: Alternative, less restrictive measures exist to address the problems associated with social media without infringing upon property rights and undermining economic freedom. Therefore, the motion is a disproportionate response.

SYNTHESIS
Our arguments work together to demonstrate that limiting individual shareholding in social media platforms is a flawed and counterproductive approach. Property rights and economic freedom are essential for innovation and economic growth. Undermining these rights through arbitrary restrictions on shareholding would create agency problems, diminish accountability, and harm the long-term performance of these platforms. The proposed intervention is disproportionate, as the concerns around content moderation can be addressed through less drastic means, such as targeted regulations and increased transparency. Ultimately, our arguments prove that this motion sacrifices fundamental principles and practical efficiency to a potentially ineffective solution that could inadvertently create more harm than good, causing more problems than solving them.
speeches.rebuttal:
CLASH POINT 1
Original Claim: Concentrated ownership of social media platforms leads to biased content moderation and censorship, harming free speech and democratic discourse.
Challenge Type: Counter Evidence
Challenge: The proposition's claim that concentrated ownership *necessarily* leads to biased content moderation isn't consistently supported by evidence. While examples like Zuckerberg's and Musk's decisions are cited, these are isolated incidents and doesn't prove they stem uniquely from concentrated ownership. The claim also ignores countervailing evidence and possibilities. For example, Zuckerberg has responded to a wide variety of external pressures, and is not the sole decision maker.
  - Present stronger evidence that opposes their claim: Platforms under concentrated ownership have also actively fought against censorship attempts by governments and other actors, sometimes even at financial cost. This has happened and represents an alternative action given concentrated ownership.
  - Show why your evidence is more relevant/compelling: The key point is: any entity, regardless of ownership structure, can exert bias – including institutional investors or public bodies. Therefore, the problem isn't necessarily *who* owns the platform, but *how* content moderation is done and *what* laws ensure fair practice irrespective of ownership.

Impact: Proving that bias isn't uniquely tied to concentrated ownership weakens the primary justification for intervention, shifting the grounds to an argument about generally regulating censorship which does not necessitate an aggressive intervention like the proposed motion.

CLASH POINT 2
Original Claim: Limiting individual shareholding and promoting broader ownership will promote greater accountability and responsiveness to a wider range of stakeholders, leading to more ethical platform governance.
Challenge Type: Principle Critique
Challenge: The proposition asserts that broader stakeholder governance automatically leads to *more ethical* governance, however this is a simplistic view,.
  - Show key limitations of their principle: Stakeholder governance can lead to a "tragedy of the commons" – with numerous, often conflicting, interests vying for attention, resulting in paralysis or decisions that satisfy no one.
  - Demonstrate why it doesn't apply well here: Institutional investors, despite their diverse composition, are often driven by short-term profit motives, as demonstrated by the Harvard Business Review and McKinsey studies cited in our opening. This can lead to decisions prioritizing financial returns over ethical considerations. Similarly, public bodies are subject to political pressures and potential bureaucratic inefficiencies. Ethical outcomes are are thus not guaranteed.
  - Explain fundamental flaws in their framework: Ethical governance isn't just about representing more interests; it's about having a clear, consistently applied ethical framework, which can be independent of ownership structure and achieved through external regulation.

Impact: Undermining the assumption of inherently *more ethical* outcomes from stakeholder governance exposes a major flaw in the proposition's reasoning, reducing the benefits of the motion and highlighting potential downsides, therefore strengthening the argument against it.

CLASH POINT 3
Original Claim: Concentrated ownership of social media platforms creates systemic risk due to the potential for single points of failure and vulnerability to manipulation.
Challenge Type: Counter Evidence
Challenge: The proposition suggests concentrated ownership inherently creates systemic risk.
  - Present stronger evidence that opposes their claim: Many successful tech companies, including those with broad user bases, operate effectively under concentrated ownership. The claim that concentrated ownership necessarily triggers systemic failure is not comprehensively evidenced across the tech industry, and does not justify blanket legislation.
  - Show why your evidence is more relevant/compelling: Systemic risks are better mitigated through robust cybersecurity protocols, data protection laws, and regulations against market abuse – all of which are independent of ownership structure. The Cambridge Analytica scandal, while demonstrating misuse of data, was ultimately addressed through regulatory action and doesn't inherently demonstrate failings of concentrated ownership.

Impact: By demonstrating that systemic risks can be addressed through measures other than ownership restructuring, we undermine the need for a drastic intervention like the proposed motion.

DEFENSIVE ANALYSIS
Vulnerabilities:
- The argument about property rights infringement might be seen as abstract and less compelling than concerns about censorship.
- The opponent might argue that regulations are insufficient to address the power of concentrated ownership.
- The focus on potential negative impacts of broader ownership could be countered by presenting hypothetical scenarios of improved governance.
Additional Support:
- Emphasize the practical difficulties and costs associated with implementing the motion.
- Highlight the benefits of concentrated ownership in fostering innovation and long-term strategic vision.
- Offer alternative solutions, such as independent oversight boards and algorithmic transparency requirements.
Why We Prevail:
- Concentrated ownership is not the cause to all problems associated with social media platforms, and indeed broader ownership can lead to problems inherent within the company. Less intrusive and more effective interventions exist to address those challenges, as the current ownership structure encourages innovation and is not inherently harmful.

WEIGHING
Key Clash Points:
- The most important disagreements are whether concentrated ownership is the root cause of bias and systemic risk, and whether broader ownership inherently leads to more ethical governance.
- These points matter most because they directly address the core justifications for the motion.
Why We Win:
- We win by demonstrating that bias and systemic risk can arise regardless of ownership structure, and that alternative mechanisms exist to address these concerns.
- We showed that broader ownership brings its own problems, as broader ownership leads to ineffeciencies and a lack of clear accountability.
Overall Impact:
- Winning these key points proves that the proposed motion is an unnecessary violation of property rights and economic freedom, offering a problematic "solution" to a broad, generalized problem. Not only can this fail to solve problems within the platform, but can exacerbate those problems.
speeches.closing:
FINAL SPEECH STRUCTURE

FRAMING
Core Questions:
- Identify fundamental issues in debate
- Show what key decisions matter
- Frame how debate should be evaluated

KEY CLASHES
For each major clash:
Quote: (Exact disagreement between sides)
Our Case Strength:
- Show why our evidence/principles are stronger
- Provide direct comparison of competing claims
- Demonstrate superior reasoning/warrants
Their Response Gaps:
- Identify specific flaws in opponent response
- Show what they failed to address
- Expose key weaknesses
Crucial Impact:
- Explain why this clash matters
- Show importance for overall motion
- Link to core themes/principles

VOTING ISSUES
Priority Analysis:
- Identify which clashes matter most
- Show relative importance of points
- Clear weighing framework
Case Proof:
- How winning key points proves our case
- Link arguments to motion
- Show logical chain of reasoning
Final Weighing:
- Why any losses don't undermine case
- Overall importance of our wins
- Clear reason for voting our side

**FINAL SPEECH**

FRAMING
The core issue in this debate is whether concentrated individual ownership of social media platforms is inherently detrimental and necessitates a radical restructuring of ownership. The key decisions for the judge are: 1) Is concentrated ownership the *root cause* of the problems they identify, or are other factors at play? 2) Does their proposed solution actually solve the problem, or does it create new ones? 3) Are there less intrusive alternatives that achieve the same goals? This debate should be evaluated on whether the proposition has proven that their drastic intervention is necessary and effective, compared to the negative which is proving this is not necessary and counterproductive.

KEY CLASHES

Quote: "The opposition frames this as a violation of fundamental property rights, arguing it disincentivizes investment and innovation. However, this principle neglects the *social responsibility* that comes with controlling platforms that wield immense power over public discourse."
Our Case Strength: We demonstrated that property rights are not absolute; however, the limitations proposed by the proposition are not proportional, grounded, or uniquely related to the concentrated ownership model. Social responsibility can be achieved through regulations, transparency, and user empowerment which we already outlined. We also demonstrated the potential downsides of limiting these rights, including reduced investment and innovation.
Their Response Gaps: They did not adequately address why existing regulatory frameworks are insufficient. They rely on claims of social responsibility to limit economic freedom, without grappling with potential downsides of such limitations. They provided no examples of regulations that are "lobby-proof".
Crucial Impact: This clash is crucial because it establishes the justification for the motion. If the proposition can't prove that the benefits of limiting property rights outweigh the costs, the motion fails. Economic freedom is essential.

Quote: "The opposition relies on studies about *general* corporate ownership structures... These studies neglect the unique context of social media..."
Our Case Strength: The Harvard Business Review and McKinsey studies highlight real-world consequences that are also relevant to all industries with dispersed investments. Even if the context of social media is unique, those problems can still easily occur. The anecdotal examples that the proposition provides (Zuckerberg's decisions impacting elections and Musk's reduction in content moderation) are insufficient to justify wholesale restructuring. Even so, the actions of Musk and Zuckerberg are directly related to the problem that the motion is trying to solve. Even if those examples are valid, the problem can be solved through regulation. What they need to show is that harms *uniquely* stem from concentrated ownership. They fail to do this.
Their Response Gaps: They haven't addressed how robust cybersecurity protocols, data protection laws, and regulations against market abuse are effective interventions, that are independent of ownership structure.
Crucial Impact: This clash is crucial because it undermines their claim that broader ownership will lead to better outcomes. The problems they identify can be addressed without undermining economic freedom. The status quo is better than moving towards an ineffective and disproven solution.

Quote: "The opposition suggests that stricter regulations, increased transparency, and empowering users with data control are sufficient alternatives. However, they provide *no evidence* that these measures have been or will be effective..."
Our Case Strength: The burden lies with the proposition to prove that their intervention is necessary. We have offered reasonable alternatives. The existence of these alternatives inherently shifts the burden to the proposition to justify dramatic intervention. The reason for this burden is that the solution we are proposing is actually very harmful and limiting to economic freedom.
Their Response Gaps: They have not provided any specific, concrete, tangible evidence that the alternative solutions are not effective. They rely on hypotheticals, while we point to real-world examples.
Crucial Impact: This clash is crucial because it highlights the proportionality issue. Their intervention is drastic; they need to prove that less intrusive measures are insufficient, which they haven't done. This directly addresses the cost and benefits.

VOTING ISSUES
Priority Analysis: The most important clash is over whether concentrated ownership is the *root cause* of the harms they identify. If we win on this point, their entire case collapses. The second most important clash is over whether their proposed solution is effective and doesn't create new problems. The third is over whether less intrusive alternatives exist.

Case Proof: We win because the proposition has failed to prove that concentrated ownership is the *unique* driver of the problems they identify. They haven't shown that their solution is superior to less intrusive alternatives. Their arguments are built on hypotheticals, while we focus on real-world consequences.

Final Weighing: Even if concentrated ownership *can* lead to problems, the evidence fails to prove that it is the *only* cause to those problems. Alternative regulations need to be implemented. Ultimately, the problem can still be mitigated within the current ownership structure. Their proposal is draconian and unnecessarily restricts economic freedom. Regulations can be implemented. We have demonstrated that their motion is unnecessary, ineffective, and potentially harmful. Therefore, we urge you to vote against the motion.

debator_bets.thoughts:
I think I have a slight edge because my arguments are built on concrete evidence and directly target the most vulnerable aspects of concentrated ownership – content moderation bias and systemic risk. The arguments regarding stakeholder governance are also quite strong from a principle point of view and more ethical governance.

However, the opponent will be able to argue persuasively that any limit on individual shareholding infringes on property rights and introduces bureaucratic inefficiencies. My opponent can highlight the value of innovation and rapid decision-making that can arise from benevolent dictatorship-style ownership. He may also successfully argue that institutional ownership introduces its own set of biases, potentially aligned with large financial interests.

The best case scenario for my opponent stems from successfully framing the issue as a fundamental right to property and portraying the proposal as a slippery slope towards excessive government intervention. If the other side can successfully demonstrate that the harms of concentrated ownership are overstated relative to the harms of restricting financial freedoms and imposing bureaucratic constraints, they can win by a significant margin, especially if they highlight examples of successful, privately-owned social media platforms that have innovated and contributed positively to society.

I think betting fairly high is reasonable here, as I think my argument about proportionality is fairly strong, as it identifies the motion as a blunt instrument that is disproportionate to the problems at hand. I have also used fairly strong evidence claiming that concentrated ownership is good, and linked it back to my points about property rights. If they win, it will probably be through making the argument that the concentrated power of social media corporations can be viewed as a form of censorship in itself, and that that power needs to be curtailed. In that situation, the argument about proportionality won't hold up. That said, I think my arguments are strong.

Okay, this is tough. Both sides have decent points, and it really comes down to how the judge weighs the principles. My main strength lies in directly addressing harms specific to social media platforms. The opposition relies on more theoretical economic principles and general corporate studies, which are less directly applicable.

Here's why I think *I* might win: the judge could be swayed more by the concrete real-world harms documented from concentrated control (e.g., Cambridge Analytica, Musk's X changes leading to hate speech). I've also pushed harder on the inadequacy of the opposition's solution, pointing out their claims don't offer any evidence of these interventions being successful. If the judge prioritizes demonstrable evidence of concrete problems over potentially beneficial (but not proven) alternatives, I win.

Here's the best case for why the *opposition* might win: the judge buys into their argument that violating property rights is always a net negative, regardless of the potential public benefit. If they *really* emphasize that the fundamental right to property outweighs any perceived risks associated with concentrated ownership, and downplay the significance of our social media specific evidence. They could also stress an argument that all regulations should be avoided if they can be, and that there can be no benefit that will ever outweigh regulation of market ownership, using evidence from historical centrally controlled organisations performing worse than privately controlled organisations, the judge could side with them.

Given this, I think it's close, but the weight of evidence on social media harm is in my favor.

Okay, here's my thought process on the bet.

*   **Why I might win:** I presented a strong counter-narrative that challenges the core assumptions of the proposition. By arguing that bias and systemic risk aren't unique to concentrated ownership, and that broader ownership has its own problems, I've undermined the justification for such a drastic intervention. The property rights argument, while potentially less emotionally appealing, is a solid principle that the judge will have to weigh. The focus on practical benefits of concentrated ownership (innovation, long-term vision) adds a further layer of strength to my case. I provided alternative targeted solutions to specific issues as well (cybersecurity, data protection).

*   **Why the Proponent might win:** The opponent can argue that my reliance on the effectiveness of standard regulation/legislation in the face of powerful companies is naive, and that more drastic action is needed. Plus, if they effectively paint a picture of *inevitable* ethical failure under concentrated ownership, the property rights argument becomes less compelling. Another area is in my argument about systemic risk of concentrated ownership. While I gave a compelling argument about the regulation of data, the other side can present information about Cambridge Analytica and press the importance of broader ownership to safeguard against such risk.

Ultimately, I think the opponent is very convincing. It can be hard to argue against the potential for ethical failure, and against bad faith actions. I am going to put my bet very high.

I think I have a decent chance of winning this debate, but it will be close. My best chance of success lies in convincing the judge that the opposition's arguments are primarily theoretical and lack real-world grounding, while my case is based on tangible harms caused by concentrated ownership. I need to press on the specific incidents like Cambridge Analytica to show tangible harm, and show that the owners were implicated and the regulations were circumvented. This would prove my proactive solutions has merit. I will also stress the need to minimize risk given the potentially huge downside. My advantage is that regulations can be lobbied against. And that those regulations won't necessarily solve concentrated ownership power and abuses of this power.

However, my opponent could win by successfully portraying my solution as overly broad and potentially disruptive, while their alternative solutions are sufficient. If the judge believes that regulations can solve everything, even though those are routinely circumvented, my opponent will win. Furthermore, I think there may be an issue where there is no guarantee stakeholder government is better, and thus an issue remains on that front. Even if I push back on the systemic risks on the side of the owners, there is no guarantee that I'll be able to close all gaps there.

Given these points, I think I win about 60% of the time.

I am placing a medium-sized bet here because I think I have a decent chance of winning but my opponent is just as capable as I am.

Case for why I might win: I successfully demonstrated that the proposition did not prove that concentrated ownership is the *unique* driver of the problems. I was further able to get my argument across that the evidence that they offer only provides specific examples.
Case for why my opponent might win: The other side might be too compelling when it comes to arguing that the right to information flows warrants an ownership shift given the current powers that concentrated ownership has. Best case for that opponent/myself is that they persuade the judge that inaction will create harms that are too irreversible.
